comments.commentBody: Not only did Mr. Der create those mind-boggling top and bottom stacks, he even put another side-to-side entry across the middle. Solving the puzzle, especially in the early going, had my mind bobbing and weaving all over the place, desperately looking for any little opening, which was an odd but enjoyable exercise because I kept finding them. The most amazing thing about this hugely entertaining puzzle was my subjective reaction to it--almost up to the time I finished it I continued to feel that it was virtually impossible to solve.

The best boutique hotel in Istanbul right now is 5 Oda (means 5 Rooms and it literally has 5 rooms). Steps from Istiklal Caddesi and Asmali Mescit, the hottest nightlife district, it is thoughtfully designed, tastefully decorated and professionally managed. Highly recommended: http://5oda.com.
"nino" is meaningless in Chile. The word for child is niño.
Why do you go back thirty and forty years to suggest that Republicans might be lying to us, when we just stay within the past year alone to know with certainty that the Democrats are lying to us?

The truth is the Democrats could have enacted real health-care reform months ago. Instead, they have used bipartisanship and the filibuster (which can be eliminated with 51 votes) as an excuse.

The system is broken and so we have "the best government money can buy." Blaming one or the other of the two money-corrupted parties only serves to divert attention from the unavoidable need for systemic change.

The Democrats should simply propose expanding the availability of Medicare to all, not just those aged 55-64. When the Republicans and health insurance lobbies predictably scream "socialized medicine," the Dems can counter-attack that:

1. Republicans don't think this program, which has cost-effectively taken care of seniors' health care financing, is good enough for able-bodied people under 65,
2. They want to get rid of it entirely, and
3. We must save Medicare and make it available to all.

Anything the Dems do on health care will get demagogued as socialized, commie-pinko Stalinist dictatorship, might as well keep it simple. Occam dictates - keep it simple: Medicare buy-in for all, with subsidies to those who have trouble affording it. Then we'll see how competitive private health insurers REALLY are.

It is almost impossible to recall any “reform” legislation that was not detrimental for the poor and the middle class or obscenely beneficial for the extremely wealthy and powerful: Welfare reform, bankruptcy reform, healthcare reform, financial reform, banking reform, election reform, etc.

Whenever our politicians, Republicans or Democrats, propose any legislation with the word “reform” in the title, watch out for your wallet and run for cover.

“Deliberately confusing gobbledygook” is the bread and butter of Congressional Republicans and their cohorts on the other side of the aisle, the best parliamentarians money can buy, the corporatista Democrats. The problem I see with Professor Krugman’s reasoning is exactly that it is reasoning. Logic, reason, reality, clearly pointing to blatant hypocrisy, we are dealing with an opposition, a disloyal and antidemocratic opposition in fact, that is immune to reason and so are the “keep gummint hands awf mah Medicare” voters who keep them in office.

If we are going to see any movement forward on this and every other issue, either the Democrats and the White House need to start borrowing from the playbook of the preceding regime, play serious hardball and just push through legislation using any and every despicable tactic available (except shame, they are immune to that as well), or create a Manhattan Project style research facility in order to develop a time machine so we can send someone back to early 1861 to convince President Lincoln that keeping the union together is a huge and tragic mistake.

I have seen the GOP "roadmap" before, and it reminds me of a story on TV recently about a county in Michigan. This county is so broke their "roadmap" is to take many secondary roads with large potholes, but no money to fix them with pavement. So instead of fixing the road, they plan to grind them back into gravel because it is cheaper to maintain than the pavement, even though it makes them dusty, rutted, and slower.

Both "roadmaps" lead us backwards. In both situations, it may be cheaper in the short term, but the long-term sustainability of either plan is suspect at best.
Once again "compassionate conservatism" rears its ugly head.

We are disgusted with our government, but not because of gridlock. We are disgusted that every one of those politicians took an oath to uphold the Constitution, and then ,most, turned around and went against much of what the Constitution states. If they would have stayed with Constitutional framework, we wouldn't have all of these debt problems, nor illegal alien problems, nor deterioaration of personal liberties problems.

We need less big government, not more. And, until we have more Constitutionally-oriented public officials, we need more gridlock, not less.

I couldn't disagree more, David, with your understanding of what has happened. It isn't that there's not a broad middle who is willing to give Obama (and government) a chance to work. The problem begins with Republicans who have opposed any action whatever, and ends with Democrats like Harry Reed (who seems to lack any ability to lead) and Pelosi, who has been as much an obstacle to Obama as the Republicans. The people are willing to see major change.... the people are willing to be led.... but the Congress of the US is bought and owned by corporate and other special interests, including the perverse idea that every Senator and House member must extract the most for his people, no matter if it destroys the US in the process or not.
It's time for a change. Obama seems to have started to break up the Republican log-jam by talking to them recently, and I hope he will keep this up (without compromising the central aspects of his policy ideas). If necessary, he should go directly to the American people and tell them that Congress is threatening the welfare of the American people, and asking them to demand change.
Please support our president, who is a bright, capable leader. We need that in these desperate times.

Good to see that you, Prez O, and all Republican senators feel the same protectionist urge toward the status quo. This means the bankers can all breath more easily as they rake in their bonuses. It means the military-industrial complex can rest assured America has no plans other than to keep relying on them full tilt. It means Industrial Ag will keep collecting its subsidies to wipe out traditional rural economies around the world -- and inject the same happy processed foods into diets abroad that have led to such obesity and ill health in America.

It means the nation's thieves profiting from abuse of health care will have no threat from any real, single-payer health program. It means the fat cats atop the admin of corporate academe will never face any challenges to their system for keeping all departments quiet and quietly separated from each other.

And it means persons like yourself can go on enjoying the good life inside the Beltway, with comfy access to all the highest government officials who face no reforms or action on anything.

But even more fundamentally, David: The American people elected Obama because they were tired of incompetence (as you mentioned), and are sick to death of the American war machine. The unholy merger of the military brass, the military suppliers, and Congress threatens the entire world. We have now been at war, one way or another, since 1960.  I remember when "the Hundred Years War" (in European history) was unthinkable!  The real test of Obama's leadership is to break the cycle of war, to break the hold the military/industrial/Congress has on this country, and to begin real nation-building.... here in the US. That's the leadership that would get Obama into the history books with a third wave of Democratic leadership!

Why is it that in the Great Depression the government, with the country in even direr straits, was able to proceed with the New Deal and the WPA. Aren't our roads crumbling, isn't there new energy to invest in?

It's bull, really. Billions for war but not a penny for the people. Dumb, rich republicans. Inert Democrats. You ought to be ashamed.

Look , this proposed legislation is bad, but compared to Obama and the Democrats trillion dollar stimulus bill, that was 'supposed' to create a ton of shovel ready jobs, it is only the second worst Democratic jobs bill offered since 2008

The Obama administration might as well for get having any movement in Congress with the elections coming! The race for the exit is speeding up with Patrick Kennedy leaving town now! Just as Scott Brown shows up too. The tide has turned.

Which part of "Medicare will bankrupt us" do you not understand, Mr. Krugman? We won't have good health if we are bankrupt. The demographics of providing subsidized medicine to seniors just won't work without massive sacrifice from the young and healthy. Check the age curve of America. That's the math we need to be doing.

Medicare opponents don't "hate" Medicare, we hate bankruptcy. On the other hand, some think of the program as a sacred cow which, if it could be replaced with a magic pill that made us all healthy all the time for zero cost, still shouldn't be. I don't get it. It's as if the act of having a program is more important than what that program actually does to us and for us.
The repeated waste that's going on has become shocking. It just keeps getting worse! These lawmakers need to lose their jobs. Too bad we have to wait for an election.

Republicans don't have a leader now and have no idea what to do as they have only Rush Limbaugh giving them direction. Democrats have been bottom feeders of the GOP for 8 years and now have no spine. Notice how many Law Makers are resigning which is due to the investigations and the fact they can no longer support the groups that give them kick back money for a vote. Americans have seen the Law Makers of both Parties have given only lip service and have really been working for Corporations. It's called take the money and run. As for Health Care we see more and more Americans dying from lack of health care with Law Makers turning their back  on the voters

On one hand we have Paul Krugman telling the Democrats to embrace the kiss of death National Health Insurance debacle that most Americans do not want, and on the other hand we have David Brooks telling the President to fully accept the Republican ideas that the President has shown some support for and have turned many Democrats against the Democratic party.

All we need is another New York Times columnist to tell the President to cosy up more with Wall Street and there will all advice needed to assure a slam dunk for the Republicans at the poll in 2010.
Republicans-If you are dumb enough to believe them they are smart enough to lie to you.

"At a minimum, a credible jobs package must extend unemployment benefits through 2010."

Why not just extend it permanently? Why are the "lucky few" who lost their jobs during a certain time entitled to indefinite unemployment payments? I happen to know some of these people and they are not actively looking for work at all, and are happy to continue to get checks as long as they keep coming.

It is obvious that Obama and the Democrat party would be happy to continue the checks as long as Congress will allow them to. By doing so you have another dependent class of Democrat voters but more importantly you don't have a large amount of people clamoring for jobs and putting political pressure on Washington to do something about it. If I am happily drawing unemployment what is the incentive to go out and look for a job? What if I get one and then get fired a month later? I would lose all of my golden geese eggs.

This whole mess is a controversy waiting to happen; the American people just haven't figured out en masse what is going on here yet. When they do this gravy train will be shut down.

We have 50% fewer nurses and 30% fewer physicians per capita than Finland. We have double the share of GDP going to health care v. Finland. We have several years shorter life expectancy. Our healthcare problem has to be solved - either on the backs of the patients (Mr. Ryan's solution) or on the backs of the providers (single payer system). In either case, malpractice reform should be a major part of the solution. Anything else including the current Congress bills simply makes the problem bigger.

In many ways Reagan was right about Medicare. It has been an utter disaster for anyone under the age of 65, and especially for America's children. Cost controls are politically difficult, so it doesn't have any. The result is a crushing tax and debt burden for under 65s, while the elderly benefit from an enormous wealth transfer from the rest of society. This is despite the fact that elderly Americans often have substantial equity in their homes and stock portfolios, the result of decades of rising house prices.

Meanwhile young families have to pay the taxes for the program, as well as paying off college loans, make mortgage payments and pay for the expenses of raising kids. Medicare is a great example of what is wrong, and right, with socialised medicine. Yes Virginia, Medicare is socialism!

It is very unfair for some people to get socialised medicine and not others. Either give it to everybody, or scrap the whole program altogether!

And the Republican criticism of the Medicare cuts is a great example of how the Republican Party has totally abandoned its principals in search of power. There may be some things wrong with what the Democrats have proposed, but the attempt to control the cost of Medicare should be strongly supported by every small government conservative, as well as every American under the age of 65.
